Name: Accountability?
Definition: The "capability of a product to enable actions of an entity to be traced uniquely to the entity" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)

Name: Accuracy
Definition: A "qualitative assessment of correctness" or "quantitative measure of the magnitude of error" (IEEE, 2013, p. 7)

Name: Adaptability
Definition: The "capability of a product to be effectively and efficiently adapted for or transferred to different hardware, software or other operational or usage environments" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Notes: Related to flexibility (IEEE, 2017, p. 12; implied by ISO/IEC, 2023a). Accessibility can improve this (and flexibility) (ISO/IEC, 2023a)

Name: Analyzability (IEEE, 2017, p. 18) or Analysability (ISO/IEC 2023a)
Definition: "The effort or resources … [required] to diagnose deficiencies or causes of failure or to identify components to be modified" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10)
Notes: Related to modifiability (IEEE, 2017, p. 18) and sub-quality of maintainability (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10)

Name: Authenticity
Definition: The "capability of a product to prove that the identity of a subject or resource is the one claimed" (ISO/IEC 2023a)

Name: Availability
Definition: The "ability of a service or service component to perform its required function at an agreed instant or over an agreed period of time" (IEEE, 2017, p. 38), or be "operational and accessible" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10)
Notes: "Normally expressed as a ratio or percentage" (IEEE, 2017, p. 38). A sub-quality of reliability (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10) and related to error tolerance, fault tolerance, reliability, and robustness (IEEE, 2017, p. 38)

Name: Behavioral Compatibility
Definition: "Identical behavior of two objects" (IEEE, 2017, p. 43; OG IEEE, 2009)
Notes: Subset of compatibility?

Name: Cohesion
Definition: The "manner and degree to which the tasks performed by a single software module are related to one another" (IEEE, 2017, p. 74)
Notes: Has the following subcategories: "coincidental, communicational, functional, logical, procedural, sequential, and temporal" (IEEE, 2017, p. 74); also called "module strength" and related to coupling (IEEE, 2017, p. 74)

Name: Comfort
Definition: The "degree to which the user is satisfied with physical comfort" (ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: Probably more oriented towards hardware systems, but may include screen brightness, colour constrast, volume levels, etc.

Name: Complexity
Definition: The "degree to which a system or component has a design or implementation that is difficult to understand and verify" (IEEE, 2017, p. 81)
Notes: A quality that software shouldn't have; constrasted with simplicity. Has the subcategory of "functional" (IEEE, 2017, p. 193)

Name: Conciseness
Definition: The degree to which functions are implemented "with a minimum amount of code" (IEEE, 2017, p. 88)

Name: Concurrency
Definition: The "property of a system in which events can occur independently of each other, and hence are not ordered" (IEEE, 2017, p. 88; OG ISO/IEC, 2004)

Name: Confidentiality
Definition: The "degree to which a product or system ensures that data are accessible only to those authorized to have access" (IEEE, 2017, p. 90; OG ISO/IEC 2011)
Precedence for Test Approach: May be a subcategory of security testing
Notes: "Data are" vs. "data is"

Name: Conformance
Definition: The degree to which "results … fall within the limits that define acceptable variation for a quality requirement" (IEEE, 2017, p. 92; OG PMBOK 5th ed.)
Precedence for Test Approach: "Conformance testing" mentioned by Washizaki (2024, p. 5-7). Conformance can be assessed (IEEE, 2017, p. 93)
Notes: Synonym for "correctness"? Related to functional testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7) and may be contrasted with nonconformity (IEEE, 2017, p. 292). May refer to the process level, not the software level

Name: Connectivity
Definition: The "capability of a system or device to be attached to other systems or devices without modification" (IEEE, 2017, p. 93; OG ISO/IEC, 2015)

Name: Consistency
Definition: The "degree of uniformity, standardization, and freedom from contradiction" (IEEE, 2017, p. 94)
Notes: "Content consistency" is a subcategory (IEEE, 2017, p. 96). Related to traceability (IEEE, 2017, p. 94)

Name: Context Coverage
Definition: The "degree to which a product or system can be used with effectiveness, efficiency, freedom from risk and satisfaction in both specified contexts of use and in contexts beyond those initially explicitly identified"
Notes: Has the sub-qualities context completeness and flexibility (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Context Completeness
Definition: The "degree to which a product or system can be used with effectiveness, efficiency, freedom from risk and satisfaction in all the specified contexts of use" (ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: Implies the existence of a "completeness" supercategory, but is a sub-quality of "context coverage" (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Correctability
Definition: The "degree of effort required to correct software defects and to cope with user complaints" (IEEE, 2017, p. 104)
Notes: Related to maintainability/modifiability (and if so, implies testing type)?

Name: Correctness
Definition: The "degree to which a system or component is free from faults in its specification, design, and implementation[,] … meet[s] specified requirements[, or] … meet[s] user needs and expectations" (IEEE, 2017, p. 104)
Notes: Synonym for "conformance"? Has the subcategory of "functional", related to "provid[ing] the correct results with the needed degree of precision" (IEEE, 2017, p. 194; OG ISO/IEC, 2011); related to functional testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7)

Name: Coupling
Definition: The "manner and degree of interdependence between software modules" or "how closely connected … [they] are" (IEEE, 2017, p. 107)
Notes: Has the following subcategories: "common‐environment", "content", "control", "data" (or "input‐output" (IEEE, 2017, p. 114)), "hybrid", and "pathological" (IEEE, 2017, p. 107). A related idea, "decoupling", seems to refer to a process rather than a quality (IEEE, 2017, p. 124)

Name: Dependability
Definition: The "trustworthiness of a computer system such that reliance can be justifiably placed on the service it delivers" (IEEE, 2017, p. 127; OG IEEE, 2005)
Precedence for Test Approach: Performance testing exists, which may be a superset of this (IEEE, 2017, p. 127; OG ISO/IEC, 2013)
Notes: Related to "availability performance and its influencing factors" (IEEE, 2017, p. 127; OG ISO/IEC, 2013)

Name: Diversity
Definition: The (amount/degree of?) "realization of the same function by different means" (IEEE, 2017, p. 143)
Notes: "Software diversity" is descibed as a "software development technique … with the intent of providing error detection, increased reliability, additional documentation, or reduced probability … [of] programming or compiler errors" (IEEE, 2017, p. 421). See also "homogeneous redundancy" (IEEE, 2017, p. 207)

Name: Effectiveness
Definition: The "accuracy and completeness with which users achieve specified goals" (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Efficiency
Definition: The "degree to which a system or component performs its designated functions with minimum consumption of resources" (IEEE, 2017, p. 154)
Precedence for Test Approach: "Performance efficiency testing" mentioned in IEEE (2022, p. 9; 2017, pp. 58, 159, 253, 442, 508)
Notes: Has the following subcategories: "execution" and "storage" (IEEE, 2017, p. 154)

Name: Error Tolerance
Definition: The "ability of a system or component to continue normal operation despite the presence of erroneous inputs" (IEEE, 2017, p. 166)
Notes: Related to fault tolerance and robustness (IEEE, 2017, p. 166)

Name: Expandability
Definition: The "degree of effort required to improve or modify software functions' efficiency" (IEEE, 2017, p. 173)
Notes: Related to extendability (IEEE, 2017, p. 173)

Name: Extendability
Definition: The "ease with which a system or component can be modified to increase its storage or functional capacity" (IEEE, 2017, p. 174)
Notes: Also called "extensibility"; related to expandability, flexibility, and maintainability (IEEE, 2017, p. 174)

Name: Fault Tolerance
Definition: "How well a system or software operates despite hardware or software faults" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10; similar in IEEE, 2017, p. 180; OG ISO/IEC 2011)
Notes: A sub-quality of reliability (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10)

Name: Flexibility
Definition: The "ease with which a system or component can be modified for use in applications or environments other than those for which it was specifically designed" (IEEE, 2017, p. 184)
Notes: "Can be measured either as the extent to which a product can be used by additional types of users to achieve additional types of goals … or by a capability to be modified to support adaptation for new types of users", etc. (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Freedom from Risk
Definition: The "degree to which a product or system mitigates the potential risk to economic status, human life, health, or the environment" (ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: Has sub-qualities that are different varities of "risk mitigation": economic, health and safety, and environmental (ISO/IEC, 2011); these seem more like functional attributes than qualities

Name: Functional Completeness
Definition: The "degree to which the set of functions covers all the specified tasks and user objectives" (IEEE, 2017, p. 193)
Notes: Implies the existence of a "completeness" supercategory

Name: Functionality
Definition: The "capabilities of the various … features provided by a product" (IEEE, 2017, p. 196)
Notes: Related to functional testing?

Name: Generality
Definition: The "degree to which a system or component performs a broad range of functions" (IEEE, 2017, p. 197)
Notes: Related to reusability (IEEE, 2017, p. 197)

Name: Immunity
Definition: The "degree to which a product or system is resistant to attack" (IEEE, 2017, p. 214; OG ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: Related to integrity (IEEE, 2017, p. 214)

Name: Integrity
Definition: The "degree to which a system, product, or component prevents unauthorized access to, or modification of, computer programs or data" (IEEE, 2017, p. 231; OG ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: Related to immunity (IEEE, 2017, p. 231)

Name: Learnability
Definition: The "degree to which a product or system can be used by specified users to achieve specified goals of learning to use the product or system with effectiveness, efficiency, freedom from risk and satisfaction in a specified context of use" or a product or system's "suitability for learning" (IEEE, 2017, p. 249)
Notes: See ISO 9241‐110

Name: Manageability
Definition: The "degree to which IT infrastructure management can attain and keep an application in its operational state" (IEEE, 2017, p. 262; OG ISO/IEC, 2015)
Notes: "Involves the transparency and manageability of applications from an infrastructure point of view" (IEEE, 2017, p. 262)

Name: Maturity
Definition: "How well a system or software can meet the need for reliability" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10; similar in IEEE, 2017, p. 266; OG ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: A sub-quality of reliability (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10)

Name: Migratability
Definition: The "ability to change the configuration, substituting one reference point of an object for another while the object is being used"(IEEE, 2017, p. 276; OG ISO/IEC, 2009)
Notes: This definition is worded weirdly. Related to portability (IEEE, 2017, p. 276)

Name: Modifiability
Definition: "The maintainer's effort associated with implementing a specified modification without introducing defects or degrading existing product quality" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10; similar in IEEE, 2017, p. 280; OG IEEE, 2015)
Notes: A sub-quality of maintainability (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10) or at the very least related; also related to analyzability and modularity (IEEE, 2017, p. 280). Implies testing type?

Name: Modularity
Definition: The "degree to which a system … is composed of discrete components such that a change to one component has minimal impact on other components" (IEEE, 2017, p.  281; OG ISO/IEC, 2011; similar in Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10 with a more vague definition of "independent")
Notes: A sub-quality of maintainability (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10); implies testing type? Related to the idea of low coupling, high cohesion, and modifiability (IEEE, 2017, p. 281)

Name: Operability
Definition: The "degree to which a product or system has attributes that make it easy to operate and control" (IEEE, 2017, p. 300; OG ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Permanence
Definition: The "degree to which failures can affect object state changes due to completed transactions" (IEEE, 2017, p. 320; OG ISO/IEC, 2009)

Name: Pleasure
Definition: The "degree to which a user obtains pleasure from fulfilling their personal needs" (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Precision
Definition: The "degree of exactness or discrimination with which a quantity is stated" (IEEE, 2017, p. 331)

Name: Presentability
Definition: The ability to "be retrieved and viewed" (IEEE, 2017, p. 333; OG IEEE, 2015)

Name: (Product) Quality
Definition: The "degree to which the product satisfies stated and implied needs when used under specified conditions" (IEEE, 2017, p. 345; OG ISO/IEC, 2012)

Name: Readability
Definition: The "ease with which a system's source code can be read and understood, especially at the detailed, statement level" (IEEE, 2017, p. 367)

Name: Recoverability
Definition: "How well a system or software can recover data during an interruption or failure" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10)
Notes: A sub-quality of reliability (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10)

Name: Replaceability
Definition: The "degree to which a product can replace another specified software product for the same purpose in the same environment" (IEEE, 2017, p. 377)
Notes: "Important … when upgrading" and "reduce[s] lock-in risk"; related to adaptibility and installability (IEEE, 2017, p. 377)

Name: Reusability
Definition: The "degree to which an asset can be used in more than one system, or in building other assets" (IEEE, 2017, p. 387; OG 2010; similar in Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10)
Notes: A sub-quality of maintainability (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10) and related to generality (IEEE, 2017, p. 387); implies testing type?

Name: Safety
Definition: "Freedom from software hazards" (IEEE, 2017, p. 427; OG 1994) or "state[s] in which human life, health, property, or the environment is endangered" "under defined conditions" (p. 397)
Precedence for Test Approach: Potentially implied by "safety requirements" (IEEE, 2017, p. 398; OG ISO/IEC, 2011) and "safety demonstrations" (IEEE, 2017, p. 397; OG ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: See ISO/IEC Guide 51

Name: Satisfaction
Definition: The "degree to which user needs are satisfied when a product or system is used in a specified context of use" or "the user’s response to interaction with the product or system" (ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: Has the following sub-qualities: usefulness, trust, pleasure, comfort; "includes attitudes towards use of the product" (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Self-Descriptiveness
Definition: The "degree to which a system or component contains enough information to explain its objectives and properties" (IEEE, 2017, p. 407)
Notes: Related to "maintainability, testability, usability" (IEEE, 2017, p. 407) and potentially the idea of being self-documented?

Name: Service Availability (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-7)
Notes: Related to availability? A subset?

Name: Service Continuity
Definition: The "capability to deliver a service without interruption, or with consistent availability as scheduled and agreed" (IEEE, 2017, p. 411)
Notes: A sub-quality of continuity? Related to service availability?

Name: Simplicity
Definition: The "degree to which a system or component has a design and implementation that is straightforward and easy to understand" (IEEE, 2017, p. 414)
Notes: Contrasted with complexity (IEEE, 2017, p. 414)

Name: Stability
Definition: A "property that an object has with respect to a given failure mode if it cannot exhibit that failure mode" (IEEE, 2017, p. 434; OG ISO/IEC, 2009)
Notes: This definition doesn't quite make sense to me

Name: Survivability
Definition: The "degree to which a product or system continues to fulfill its mission by providing essential services in a timely manner in spite of the presence of attacks" (IEEE, 2017, p. 450; OG ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: Related to recoverability (IEEE, 2017, p. 450)

Name: Testability
Definition: The "degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which test criteria can be established … and tests can be performed to determine whether those criteria have been met" (IEEE, 2017, p. 473; OG ISO/IEC, 2014); "the effort … [required] to test the modified software" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10)
Notes: A sub-quality of maintainability (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10); implies testing type?

Name: Traceability
Definition: The "degree to which a relationship can be established between two or more products of the development process" (IEEE, 2017, p. 481; OG ISO/IEC, 2012) or "to which each [software] element … establishes its reason for existing" (IEEE, 2017, p. 481; OG ISO/IEC, 2010)
Notes: Can be aided with the use of a traceability matrix (IEEE, 2017, p. 482)

Name: Trust
Definition: The "degree to which a user or other stakeholder has confidence that a product or system will behave as intended" (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Unambiguity
Definition: The degree to which something is "described in terms that only allow a single interpretation" (IEEE, 2017, p. 488; OG IEEE, 2015)
Notes: Applicable to software, or just documentation?

Name: Understandability
Definition: The "ease with which a system can be comprehended at both the system‐organizational and detailed‐statement levels" (IEEE, 2017, p. 489)
Notes: More general than readability and applicable to the system as a whole (IEEE, 2017, p. 489)

Name: Usefulness
Definition: The "degree to which a user is satisfied with their perceived achievement of pragmatic goals, including the results of use and the consequences of use" (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: User-Friendliness?
Definition: The degree to which a system is easy and convenient to use (IEEE, 2017, p. 498)
Notes: Difference between this and usability?
